folder: Spring Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Spring Street, north side, from Washington to Greenwich Streets, and east, showing the three old frame houses Nos. 323-319, adjoining and at the N.W. corner of Greenwich Street.
September 27, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Spring Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Spring Street, north side, from West to Washington Streets, inclusive, showing the filling station on the site of 353-359 Spring Street, demolished in 1927, and the demolition of the old warehouse at 347-341 Spring Street.

June 3, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Spring Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Demolition of 353-349 Spring Street, three six-story tenement houses at and adjoining the N.E. corner of West Street.
October 25, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Washington Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Washington Street, northeast corner and Spring Street, south of Charlton Street.

(2) Washington Street at southeast corner of Charlton after demolition of building at northeast corner.

P. L. Sperr
August 29, 1930
Views 1,2

folder: Washington Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY
text:

folder: Spring Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Spring Street, north side, from the site of 341 Spring, west of Washington Street, to and including Hudson Street.
June 23, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Spring Street, north side, from the site of 341 Spring Street (demolished in 1930) to and including Greenwich Street.
March 19, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 2. The buildings seen across the clearance (at the N.W. corner) are No. 333 Spring Street (at the N.E. corner) and Nos. 499 to 511 Washington Street (adjoining and north of same corner). Note on Greenwich Street the Ninth Ave. Elevated Line.

August 3, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Morton and Barrow Streets, Manhattan, N.Y.
title: Squatters Colony between Morton and Barrow Streets.

folder: Morton and Barrow Streets, Manhattan, N.Y.
title: Squatters Colony between Morton and Barrow Streets.

folder: Washington Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Washington Street, north from and including Spring Street, showing the demolition work in process on the west side.
November 9, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, three and a half years later, showing the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal which fills the space between Washington and West Streets, from a little south of Charlton Street, which has been replaced by a service drive, to Clarkson Street.
March 1, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 2, several years later. This new terminal was erected here as a part of the West Side Improvement and Track Removal Project of the New York Central Railroad. It replaced the original, which occupied the block (former park of same name) bounded by Hudson, Varick, Beach and Light Streets.

November 3, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Washington Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Washington Street, north from Spring Street. To the left is the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal of the N.Y.C.R.R. Note the W.P.A. street car track removal project.

April 28, 1937

W.P.A.Photo
Five Boroughs Project

(2)
Washington Street, north from Spring Street.

P. L. Sperr
October 2, 1938
